body: Desire is to have the same number of tests run on any platform (although skipped tests are expected to be different) as this makes it easy to see that all tests were run.  We should fix this sooner so other people don't copy this as an acceptable pattern.

Do we need to fix this?
powershell\Modules\Microsoft.PowerShell.Utility\Implicit.Remoting.Tests.ps1:39:            return
powershell\engine\Help\HelpSystem.Tests.ps1:112:        if ($IsWindows)

The reason I chose the global scope was to be _sure_ that it got reset it back to it's original state. Pester creates quite a number of scopes, and I wanted to be sure that I reset the value as high in the scope chain as I could.

WRT: Implicit.Remoting.Tests.ps1 - this looks fine, the tests should report regardless of platform. the return after setting $skiptest is proper as the BeforeAll shouldn't continue to execute.
WRT: HelpSystem.Tests.ps1 - the architecture of these tests is going to make this a bit tricky. Pester doesn't have a way to skip a test based on the _contents_ of a testcase (although that would be a cool thing). This may need to be deconstructed into a foreach loop

@JamesWTruher Thanks for clarification!
> I reset the value as high in the scope chain as I could.

It seems Pester's scopes are bit tricky. However, wouldn't it be more correct to restore the value in the same scope where the change was made? The same we do for `$ProgressPreference = $SavedProgressPreference`

> WRT: HelpSystem.Tests.ps1 - the architecture of these tests is going to make this a bit tricky

I don't understand why tests split on "Windows" and "non-Windows" in `testcases` and skipped ALL for "non-Windows"?
```powershell
    It -Skip:(-not $IsWindows) "shows contextual help when Get-Help is invoked for provider-specific path (Get-Help -Name <verb>-<noun> -Path <path>)" -TestCases $testCases {
```
Should the tests (from first `testcase`) be performed on non-Windows? Or should I make them `pending` or `skipped`?
Today we have 4609 Travis test and 4681 Appveyor test. So we "lost" 72 tests. Need a way to catch them.
yep. FWIW, even if the numbers are the same, it may be that different tests are running. We need more tooling to compare the test runs across platforms
Yes. It is more common so I open new Issue.
